model_wind_w.description:

platform_roll.description:
Roll angle `(platform_roll)`

platform_yaw.description:
Yaw angle `(platform_yaw)`

radar_constant.description:
Radar constant

radar_constant_correction_factor.description:
Radar constant correction factor  

Radar constant correction factor (near field correction, noisecom calibration, original variable 'SNRCorFaCo')

radar_cross_correlation.description:
Cross-correlation coefficient 

Correlation between the IQ signals measured in the cross- and co-channel

radar_differential_phase.description:
Differential phase 

Differential phase of the backscattered signal measured between co- and cross-channel

radar_doppler_velocity.description:
Doppler velocity (uncorrected) `(radial_velocity_of_scatterers_toward_instrument)` 

Line of sight doppler velocity (towards the instrument is positive)

radar_doppler_velocity_corrected.description:
Doppler velocity (corrected) `(radial_velocity_of_scatterers_toward_instrument)` 

Vertical doppler velocity (upward is positive, motion corrected, horizontal wind corrected)

radar_doppler_velocity_corrected_no_wind.description:
Doppler velocity (corrected, no h-wind) `(radial_velocity_of_scatterers_toward_instrument)` 

Vertical doppler velocity (upward is positive, motion corrected)

radar_doppler_velocity_peaks.description:
Doppler velocity peaks 

Number of line of sight doppler velocity peaks

radar_doppler_velocity_skewness.description:
Doppler velocity skewness 

Line of sight doppler velocity skewness (influenced by platform motion)

radar_doppler_velocity_width.description:
Doppler velocity width 

Line of sight doppler velocity width (broadened by platform motion)

radar_gaseous_attenuation.description:
Path integrated gaseous attenuation (PIA) 

Path integrated attenuation (2-way, linear) due to water vapour and oxygen

radar_instrument_mask.description:
Radar instrument mask 


0=valid radar measurements / -1=below WGS84 geoid/ -2=ground clutter / -3=above platform / -4=radar non operational / -5=radar sensitivity suboptimal / -6=radar calibration / -7=platform in curve (roll lt 5) / -8=radar data not available / -9=below topography / -10=above LDR thresold (-10 dB)

radar_linear_depolarization_ratio.description:
Linear depolarization ratio 

Ratio between the radar reflectivities measured in the cross- and co-channel

radar_off_nadir_angle.description:
Angle of incidence `(angle_of_incidence)` 

The angle of incidence between the beam direction and the normal of the ground.

radar_reflectivity.description:
Equivalent reflectivity factor `(equivalent_reflectivity_factor)` 

The factor is calculated from the measured radar return power assuming the target is composed of liquid water droplets (K^2=0.93) scattering in the Rayleigh regime

radar_signal_to_noise.description: Radar signal to noise ratio as determined with the Hildebrand and Sekhorn method

time_original.description:
Time `(time)` 

Seconds since UTC epoch (original measurement time)

properties.title: Integrated Water Vapor Retrieval from the K-Band and W-Band Microwave Radiometers
properties.description: This dataset contains retrievals of integrated water vapor (IWV) from the KV-band microwave radiometer onboard the HALO aircraft during the ORCESTRA campaign. The retrieval is based on a linear regression model and should not be used for quantitative analysis. The purpose of this data was to provide an estimate of IWV during the flights. The processing includes formatting the data, adding georeference information, filtering for altitudes above 4800 m and adding a land-sea mask.
properties.processing:lineage: The processing software is available at https://github.com/orcestra-campaign/hamp_processing

mask_sea_land.description:
Mask for sea and land. 

1 indicates sea, 0 indicates land.

properties.title: MIRA Cloud Radar Moments from the HALO Microwave Package (Level 3)
properties.description: This dataset contains measurements from the MIRA cloud radar onboard the HALO aircraft during the ORCESTRA campaign. The measurements are processed and quality controlled. The processing includes formatting the data, adding georeference information, filtering for noise, clutter and valid radar states, and adding masks for calibration, ground reflections, and roll segments.
properties.processing:lineage: The processing software is available at https://github.com/orcestra-campaign/hamp_processing

DetuneFine.description: Detuning of the Local Oscillator Detected from Txn Footprint

LDRnormal.description: LDR calculated by weigting both channels withe the SNR of the more powerful channel

NyquistVelocity.description: Speed of Light  * Pulse Repetition Frequency / (4 * Frequency)

RadarConst.description: Radar Constant related to 5 km Height, and 200 ns pulses. Z = SNR * RadarConst * (range/5 km)^2 * SNRCorFaCo. It changes slightly in time due to the measured transmit power

SNRCorFaCo.description: Factor to correct Co-channel SNR based on Receiver calibration measurement by Noisecom source

SNRCorFaCx.description: Factor to correct Cx-channel SNR based on Receiver calibration measurement by Noisecom source. LDR = SNRcx/SNRco * SnrCorFaCx/SnrCorFaCo

Ze.description: Equivalent Radar Reflectivity Factor Ze of Hydrometeors

Zg.description: Equivalent Radar Reflectivity Factor Ze of all Targets

azi.description: Azimut Angle, if > 370 azi-720 represents the middle of the averaging interval, if azi < 370 then azi represents the position of the end of the next data block.

dBZe.description: Decadal logarithm of equivalent radar reflectivity of hydrometeors (Ze)

dBZg.description: Decadal logarithm of equivalent radar reflectivity of all targets (Zg)

elv.description: Elevation Angle, if > 370 elv-720 represents the middle of the averaging interval, if elv < 370 then elv represents the position of the end of the next data block.

mask_calibration.description:
Mask for radar calibration segments 

1 indicates no radar calibration, 0 indicates radar calibration

mask_ground_return.description:
Mask for ground reflections 

1 indicates no ground reflection, 0 indicates ground reflection

mask_roll.description:
Mask for roll segments 

0 indicates roll higher 5 deg, 1 indicates roll lower 5 deg

npw1.unit: Sum over the Spectrum in DSP units

npw2.unit: Sum over the Spectrum in DSP units

properties.title: BEACH dropsonde dataset (Level 3)
properties.description: This dataset is the Level 3 BEACH dataset. It contains quality controlled dropsonde data from the ORCESTRA field campaign with a common altitude dimension. All thermodynamic and dynamic variables are (re-)calculated consistently within the dataset and integrated quantities such as integrated water vapour are added. As such, the Level 3 dataset is the core dataset of BEACH and should be the default for any analysis. It is based on BEACH Level 2 datasets of single sonde profiles. Aggregated QC information can be found in the `sonde_qc` variables and further details are stored in the separate Level_3_QC dataset or respective Level 2 datasets. For analyses using the time, refer to the BEACH Level 2. Circle products, like mesoscale divergence and vertical velocity can be found in BEACH Level 4.
properties.processing:lineage:
Level 1 ASPEN processing with Aspen V4.0.4 
Level 2 quality control with pydropsonde 0.5.0 
Level 3 processing with pydropsonde 0.5.0 
Level 3 concatenation with pydropsonde 0.5.0

properties.title: BEACH dropsonde dataset (Level 4)
properties.description: This dataset is the Level 4 BEACH dataset. It contains only the sondes that belong to a circle flight pattern during ORCESTRA. The sondes in circles were used to derive so called circle products, which describe the horizontal divergence, vertical velocity, and vorticity on the mesoscale (Bony and Stevens, 2019). Single sonde profiles were first interpolated applying the Akima-splines method before calculating circle products. All sonde profile variables have the dimension `sonde` and are stored in a ragged array structure, while all circle products have the dimension `circle`. For non-interpolated sonde data and sondes that do not belong to a circle, refer to BEACH Level 3.
properties.processing:lineage:
Level 1 ASPEN processing with Aspen V4.0.4 
Level 2 quality control with pydropsonde 0.5.0 
Level 3 processing with pydropsonde 0.5.0 
Level 3 concatenation with pydropsonde 0.5.0 
Level 4 computation with pydropsonde 0.5.0

properties.title: HALO position and attitude data during the PERCUSION campaign
properties.description: This dataset provides a best estimate of the position and attitude of the HALO aircraft during the ORCESTRA campaign. In general, 100Hz data from the IGI system is used (see the `source` attribute of the per-flight datasets when in doubt).

properties.title: Shipboard ADCP current measurements (38 kHz) during RV METEOR cruise M203
properties.description: Current velocities of the upper water column along the cruise track of R/V Meteor cruise M203 were collected by a vessel-mounted 38 kHz RDI Ocean Surveyor ADCP. The ADCP transducer was located at 5.0 m below the water line. The instrument was operated in narrowband mode (WM10) with a bin size of 32.00 m, a blanking distance of 16.00 m, and a total of 55 bins, covering the depth range between 53.0 m and 1781.0 m. Attitude data from the ship's motion reference unit were used by the data acquisition software VmDAS internally to convert ADCP beam velocities to geographic coordinates. The Python toolbox OSADCP (version 2.0.0) was used for data post-processing. Single-ping data were screened for bottom signals and, where appropriate, a bottom mask was manually processed. Acoustic Interferences were identified based on outliers in the ADCP echo intensity data. Echo intensity data were cleaned accordingly and affected velocity cells were flagged to be removed prior ensemble-averaging. The ship's velocity was calculated from position fixes obtained by the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS), taking into account lever arms of ADCP transducer and GNSS antenna. Accuracy of the derived water velocities mainly depends on the quality of the position fixes and the ship's heading data. Further errors stem from a misalignment of the transducer with the ship's centerline. Data processing included water track calibration of the misalignment angle (0.0691° +/- 0.5613°) and scale factor (1.0054 +/- 0.0088) of the measured velocities. The velocity data were averaged in time using an average interval of 60 s. Depth cells with ensemble-averaged percent-good values below 25% are marked as 'bad data'.
properties.processing:lineage: 2024-11-21T06:34:03Z: initial saving of data in NetCDF format; 2025-01-30T13:13:28Z: converted to Zarr by Lukas Kluft (lukas.kluft@mpimet.mpg.de)

DEPTH.description: depth of cell center below sea surface `(depth)`

TIME.description: time relative to reference date time

ECHO_INTENSITY.description: beam-averaged echo intensity of Teledyne RDI ADCP instrument

ECHO_INTENSITY_CLEANED.description: beam-averaged echo intensity of Teledyne RDI ADCP instrument after editing out single-ping-interferences

PERCENT_GOOD.description: percent of good data per ensemble average

PINGS_PER_ENSEMBLE.description: pings of Teledyne RDI ADCP instrument averaged to a double ensemble value

properties.title: Shipboard ADCP current measurements (75 kHz) during RV METEOR cruise M203
properties.description: Current velocities of the upper water column along the cruise track of R/V Meteor cruise M203 were collected by a vessel-mounted 75 kHz RDI Ocean Surveyor ADCP. The ADCP transducer was located at 5.0 m below the water line. The instrument was operated in narrowband mode (WM10) with a bin size of 8.00 m, a blanking distance of 4.00 m, and a total of 100 bins, covering the depth range between 17.0 m and 809.0 m. Attitude data from the ship's motion reference unit were used by the data acquisition software VmDAS internally to convert ADCP beam velocities to geographic coordinates. The Python toolbox OSADCP (version 2.0.0) was used for data post-processing. Single-ping data were screened for bottom signals and, where appropriate, a bottom mask was manually processed. Acoustic Interferences were identified based on outliers in the ADCP echo intensity data. Echo intensity data were cleaned accordingly and affected velocity cells were flagged to be removed prior ensemble-averaging. The ship's velocity was calculated from position fixes obtained by the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS), taking into account lever arms of ADCP transducer and GNSS antenna. Accuracy of the derived water velocities mainly depends on the quality of the position fixes and the ship's heading data. Further errors stem from a misalignment of the transducer with the ship's centerline. Data processing included water track calibration of the misalignment angle (-46.4281° +/- 0.5612°) and scale factor (1.0069 +/- 0.0086) of the measured velocities. The velocity data were averaged in time using an average interval of 60 s. Depth cells with ensemble-averaged percent-good values below 25% are marked as 'bad data'.
properties.processing:lineage: 2024-11-21T13:50:02Z: initial saving of data in NetCDF format; 2025-01-30T13:13:33Z: converted to Zarr by Lukas Kluft (lukas.kluft@mpimet.mpg.de)

DEPTH.description: depth of cell center below sea surface `(depth)`

TIME.description: time relative to reference date time

ECHO_INTENSITY.description: beam-averaged echo intensity of Teledyne RDI ADCP instrument

ECHO_INTENSITY_CLEANED.description: beam-averaged echo intensity of Teledyne RDI ADCP instrument after editing out single-ping-interferences

PERCENT_GOOD.description: percent of good data per ensemble average

PINGS_PER_ENSEMBLE.description: pings of Teledyne RDI ADCP instrument averaged to a double ensemble value

properties.title: IWV data from GNSS antenna on R/V METEOR
properties.description: ZTD are screened using range check and outlier check on both position and ZTD. ZTD are converted to IWV using ERA5 sea level pressure data, 1-hourly, 0.25x0.25 deg and VMF1 atmospheric integrated mean temperature, 6-hourly,  2.0x2.5 deg. See [Bosser et al., 2021, ESSD] for more information.

properties.title: X-band Radar surface derived currents M203
properties.description: Radar derived surface currents, based in linear waves dispersion relation properties. The retrieved currents  are based on the frequency shifts observed by the radar within the wave field observations.A Helmholtz-Zentrum Hereon marine X-band radar was installed in RV Meteorfrom August 10th 2024 to March 17th 2025. An external GPS was also installed to geolocate the radar backscatter-Intensity data. The radar was equipped with a 7.5' (2.3 m) wide antenna with vertical polarization in transmit and receive (VV) and operated in short pulse mode with a pulse duration of 50 to 70 ns, a pulse repetition frequency of 2000 Hz, and a nominal transmitted peak power of 12 kW. These settings yield a nominal resolution at the -3 dB level of 7.5 to 10.5 m and about 1° in range and azimuth, respectively. The recieved signal was digitized at 40 MHz with 1504 sampled range cells yielding a spatial sampling distance of 3.75 m, and a maximum range of roughly 5640 km. The radar was scheduled to continuously record data in the standard scanning mode, that is at an antenna rotation period of roughly 2 seconds. The radar was operated as needed, based on the Meteor crew's requirements. During the first two weeks, some data was lost due to hard drive storage failures. That issue was resolved, and the remaining data gaps are due to intentional shutdowns requested by the crew.
properties.processing:lineage: Original dataset created by Ruben Carrasco (ruben.carrasco@hereon.de) on 20250903T155103Z; Converted to Zarr by Lukas Kluft (lukas.kluft@mpimet.mpg.de)

northward_sea_water_velocity.description: northward component of the near surface current velocity `(northward_sea_water_velocity)`

properties.title: Horizontal wind profiles from shipborne scanning wind lidar
properties.description: During BOW-TIE (ORCESTRA) a scanning motion-stabilized wind lidar on the RV Meteor performed various scanning routines to look at profiles and cross sections of the horizontal wind components. This dataset presents the horizontal wind profiles over the lowest 1-2 kilometer of the atmosphere retrieved from the Doppler Beam Swinging (DBS) scanning mode. Each DBS sweep involves pointing the lidar beam at four azimuth angles (0,90,180,270 degrees) around a scanning circle at an elevation angle of 80 degrees followed by one vertically pointing beam. The DBS method assumes that the instantaneous velocity field is homogeneous across the scanning circle. During the final part of the cruise, as indicated by a flag, the stabilization platform was disabled. Motion stabilization is not critical for DBS wind profiles when averaged over longer time windows (10 min or longer); however, scrutiny is advised.
properties.processing:lineage: Created from original file WLS200s-180-2024-08-17-%H-%M-%S-dbs-1397-25m.nc on project drive Windcube at TU Delft

properties.title: METEOR1 PARSIVEL Disdrometer QCed data
properties.description:
This dataset corresponds to one of two PARSIVEL disdrometers aboard
the RV Meteor. This version underwent a QC process and data products
for research were added.

*QC process:
A quality control method developed by the Central Weather Administration of Taiwan
was implemented. QC follows the work of Lu et al. (2020) and Friedrich et al. (2013)
and the procedure only processes liquid rain. No hail or graupel remains after QC.

*Research variables:
In addition to the variables provided by the raw parsivel data,
this version also includes data products for microphysical
and radar analysis. These include drop-size distribution moments
and simulated dual-polarization radar quantities at different
wavelengths.

More information on the data, QC process and postprocessed products
can be found in the README file.

properties.title: Merged PARSIVEL Disdrometer QCed data
properties.description:
The merged version contains data from the disdrometer (either METEOR1 or METEOR2)
that showed the greatest rain rate (RR) after QC at a given timestep. The variable
“greatest_RR_flag” with values of either 1 or 2, indicates from which disdrometer the
data is during that time step. Some raw variables, were eliminated during this porcess.

*QC process perfomed:
A quality control method developed by the Central Weather Administration of Taiwan
was implemented. QC follows the work of Lu et al. (2020) and Friedrich et al. (2013)
and the procedure only processes liquid rain. No hail or graupel remains after QC.

*Research variables:
In addition to the variables provided by the raw parsivel data,
this version also includes data products for microphysical
and radar analysis. These include drop-size distribution moments
and simulated dual-polarization radar quantities at different
wavelengths.

More information on the data, QC process and postprocessed products
can be found in the README file.

properties.title: surface rain flag from Micro Rain Radar
properties.description: Flag for rain occurence retrieved from the Micro Rain Radar measurement. Therefore, the observed reflectivity in secondlowest radar range gate (120m)?

properties.title: Rain gauge measurements during METEOR cruise M203
properties.description:
The rain gauge has an upper and a lateral collecting surface on which the precipitation is converted into digital pulses via droplet formers. The pulses are recorded by the data logger as counting pulses via two digital inputs and transmitted to the meteorological computer via the RS422-interface.

The precipitation detector serves as a signalling device for determining the start and end of precipitation. The precipitation is recorded by a light barrier system and triggers a switching signal, which is recorded via a digital status input of the data logger. The precipitation duration is determined in the METCO by integrating the status signal over time.

The sensitivity of the precipitation detection is 0.05 mm/h or less.
properties.processing:lineage: Converted to Zarr by Lukas Kluft (lukas.kluft@mpimet.mpg.de)

properties.title: Continuous thermosalinograph salinity and temperature data along RV METEOR M203 cruise track
properties.description:
During R/V Meteor cruise M203 (BOW-TIE) from August 10 to September 23, 2024, 
underway sea surface temperature and sea surface salinity data were taken at 
at 5m depth using a thermosalinograph. The data were collected in the framework
of the ORCESTRA campaign (https://orcestra-campaign.org/)
references: 'Schlundt, M; Klocke, D; Dengler, M (2025): Continuous thermosalinograph oceanography along RV METEOR cruise track M203 [dataset], PANGAEA,  https://doi.pangaea.de/10.1594/PANGAEA.977775'
properties.processing:lineage: Version 1

properties.title: Clear-air vertical velocity during ORCESTRA retrieved from Meteosat water vapor brightness temperatures
properties.description:
This dataset contains clear air vertical velocity retrievals over the tropical Atlantic during the ORCESTRA field campaign.
The retrievals are based on the methodology described in Poujol and Bony (2024)
Vertical velocity is inferred from brightness temperature in the water vapor absorption band.
Two channels are used: the channel at 6.2µm that sounds the upper troposphere, and the channel at 7.3µm that sounds the mid-troposphere.
The dataset is provided with hourly time resolution and on the native satellite grid (about 3 km horizontal resolution). Two levels are provided for the two channels.
For each level, the vertical pressure velocity and its standard error are provided. Also, an estimate of emission level temperature is provided and corresponds to the vertical coordinate.
Note that emission level temperature varies in space and time.
An estimate of the emission level pressure is also provided but is based on interpolation with respect to a moist adiabatic temperature profile.
Therefore, emission level temperature should be used preferentially as a vertical coordinate.
For further details on the retrieval method, its biases and uncertainties, refer to Poujol and Bony (2024).
references: "Poujol and Bony (2024). Measuring Clear-Air vertical Motions from Space, AGU Advances. https://doi.org/10.1029/2024AV001267"

T_em.description: Air temperature at the emission level `(air_temperature)`

omega.description: vertical velocity at the emission level `(lagrangian_tendency_of_air_pressure)`

err_omega.description: Standard error on the vertical velocity at the emission level `(standard_error_of_lagrangian_tendency_of_air_pressure)`

properties.title: RAPSODI Oscillating Radiosonde Measurements during ORCESTRA (Level 1)
properties.description: Radiosondes launched from R/V Meteor during intense rain exhibited repeated ascent–descent cycles near the freezing level (~5000 m) before ultimately reaching burst altitude. One case began above the freezing level. A plausible explanation is temporary icing on a moistened balloon that melts during descent, though a strong stable layer could also contribute. Similar oscillatory behavior has been reported previously.
properties.processing:lineage: Processed from Vaisala .mwx files using 00_Process_Oscillating_mwx_files.py; aligned with functions from pysonde

sonde_id.description:
sounding identifier 

Unique string describing the sounding's origin (PLATFORM_TIME)

alt.description:
ellipsoidal vertical position (WGS84, from GPS) `(altitude)` 

Altitude measured by radisonde

dz.description:
ascent/descent rate of measuring device `(ascent_descent_rate)` 

ascent rate is positive/ decent rate is negative

p.description:
